articles.headline: Justices Bar Mandatory Life Terms for Juveniles
articles.snippet: The justices ruled that such sentencing for those under 18 violated the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled that such sentencing for those under 18 violated the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some 2,000 juvenile offenders serving life sentences without parole were given hope of eventual release by the Supreme Court on Monday. The court ruled that laws requiring youths convicted of murder to be sentenced to die in prison violate the Eighth Amendment’s ban on cruel and unusual punishment.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Microsoft to Buy Yammer for $1.2 Billion
articles.snippet: Microsoft announced on Monday that it would buy Yammer, a social networking service for businesses, for $1.2 billion in cash, as it seeks to strengthen its enterprise software business and compete more directly with Salesforce.com.
articles.abstract: Microsoft announced on Monday that it would buy Yammer, a social networking service for businesses, for $1.2 billion in cash, as it seeks to strengthen its enterprise software business and compete more directly with Salesforce.com.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft announced on Monday that it would buy Yammer, a social network service for businesses, for $1.2 billion in cash, as it seeks to strengthen its enterprise software business and compete more directly with Salesforce.com.
articles.byline: By Evelyn M. Rusli and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: With No Vote, Taxpayers Stuck With Tab on Bonds
articles.snippet: Surprised taxpayers are finding themselves obligated for parking garages, hockey arenas and other enterprises that can no longer pay their debts.
articles.abstract: Surprised taxpayers are finding themselves obligated for parking garages, hockey arenas and other enterprises that can no longer pay their debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Surprised local taxpayers from Stockton, Calif., to Scranton, Pa., are finding themselves obligated for parking garages, hockey arenas and other enterprises that can no longer pay their debts.

articles.headline: How Many Computers to Identify a Cat? 16,000
articles.snippet: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.
articles.abstract: A neural network of computer processors, fed millions of YouTube videos, taught itself to recognize cats, a feat of significance for fields like speech recognition.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Inside Google’s secretive X laboratory, known for inventing self-driving cars and augmented reality glasses, a small group of researchers began working several years ago on a simulation of the human brain.

articles.headline: Turkish Border Is Crucial Link in Syrian Conflict
articles.snippet: A network of activists has taken advantage of the tensions between Turkey and Syria to build a supply chain for those opposed to President Bashar al-Assad’s government.
articles.abstract: A network of activists has taken advantage of the tensions between Turkey and Syria to build a supply chain for those opposed to President Bashar al-Assad’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — The onetime ragtag militias of the Syrian opposition are developing into a more effective fighting force with the help of an increasingly sophisticated network of activists here in southern Turkey that is smuggling crucial supplies across the border, including weapons, communications gear, field hospitals and even salaries for soldiers who defect.

articles.headline: Zynga Pursues New Hits for a Fickle Market
articles.snippet: The social game company, faced with a declining share price, is trying to figure out how to recover its early momentum as interest in its most popular games is waning.
articles.abstract: The social game company, faced with a declining share price, is trying to figure out how to recover its early momentum as interest in its most popular games is waning.
articles.lead_paragraph: The social game company Zynga hit it big in 2009 with FarmVille, a phenomenon on Facebook that had millions of people watering virtual corn.

articles.headline: ‘Big Brother’? No, It’s Parents
articles.snippet: An array of surveillance software now exists to let parents keep tabs on their children’s activities online, raising questions about appropriate parenting.
articles.abstract: An array of surveillance software now exists to let parents keep tabs on their children’s activities online, raising questions about appropriate parenting.
articles.lead_paragraph: When her children were ready to have laptops of their own, Jill Ross bought software that would keep an eye on where they went online. One day it offered her a real surprise. She discovered that her 16-year-old daughter had set up her own video channel.

articles.headline: Rate of Killings Rises 38 Percent in Chicago in 2012
articles.snippet: The increasing violence has left its largest scars in some of the city’s most impoverished, struggling neighborhoods on the South and West Sides.
articles.abstract: The increasing violence has left its largest scars in some of the city’s most impoverished, struggling neighborhoods on the South and West Sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s first reading material each morning, at 5:30, is not a budget update, a legislative proposal or a packet of headlines. It is an e-mail from the Chicago Police Department listing the crimes that were committed during the night that just ended. By 7 a.m., he is calling Garry F. McCarthy, the police superintendent. That is unlikely to be their final conversation of the day, or even of the morning.

articles.headline: Backed by NATO, Turkey Steps Up Warning to Syria
articles.snippet: Turkey escalated its warnings, even as some American and allied officials privately raised questions about whether the Turkish warplane shot down by Syria had been on a spy mission.
articles.abstract: Turkey escalated its warnings, even as some American and allied officials privately raised questions about whether the Turkish warplane shot down by Syria had been on a spy mission.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Buoyed by support from its NATO allies, Turkey escalated its warnings against Syria on Tuesday, even as some American and allied officials privately raised questions about whether the Turkish warplane shot down by Syrian air defenses — provoking the denunciation — had been on a spy mission.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Sebnem Arsu
